Based on the following question, analyze it carefully and provide your probability estimate.

Question: Will the global surface air temperature on April 1, 2025 be between 14.3°C and 14.7°C (inclusive)?
Background: In 2024, the global average temperature was 1.47°C higher than pre-industrial levels, [according to NASA](https://www.nasa.gov/news-release/temperatures-rising-nasa-confirms-2024-warmest-year-on-record/) and 1.6°C higher [according to the EU's Copernicus Climate Change Service](https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2025/jan/10/world-temperature-in-2024-exceeded-15c-for-first-time), marking the hottest year since records began in 1850. This warming trend has been linked to an increase in extreme weather events, including severe heatwaves, hurricanes, floods, and droughts.

​In 2025, global temperatures are [projected to be](https://www.metoffice.gov.uk/about-us/news-and-media/media-centre/weather-and-climate-news/2024/2025-global-temperature-outlook) among the highest on record, continuing the trend of recent years. US's National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration [forecasted a 7.1% chance](https://www.ncei.noaa.gov/access/monitoring/monthly-report/global/202501/page-2) that 2025 would be the warmest on record. Despite that, January's temperatures [surpassed all records](https://www.bbc.co.uk/weather/articles/cdxnpr8xwjno) for that month. The question asks whether the temperature on April 1, 2025 will be between 14.3°C and 14.7°C (inclusive).
Resolution criteria: This question will resolve as YES if the daily average global surface air temperature for April 1, 2025, in the ERA5 data, as reported by [Copernicus's Climate Pulse](https://pulse.climate.copernicus.eu/), is between 14.3°C and 14.7°C (inclusive).

* If the resolution source ceases to report that data, Metaculus might consult additional sources, provided they use the same underlying dataset.
